summary: Yuriy Ivanovich Nosenko was a KGB officer who defected to the United States. A significant portion of the documents relate to the CIA's investigation into Nosenko's bona fides, including interviews, polygraph tests, and analysis to determine if he was a genuine defector or a KGB plant. The documents also reveal that Nosenko was questioned about the Wallenberg case. Nosenko's name appears in the context of the ARRB meetings concerning the release of CIA records related to the JFK assassination, specifically regarding the opening of Nosenko NBR material. He testified before the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) regarding Lee Harvey Oswald's time in the Soviet Union and the KGB's alleged lack of interest in him. The documents also mention efforts to verify and correct transcriptions of a 1962 tape involving Nosenko, focusing on whether he stated he had been in the United States or used the alias Nikolayev there.
significance: Nosenko's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his role as a KGB defector who provided information about Lee Harvey Oswald's time in the Soviet Union. His testimony and the CIA's assessment of his credibility were relevant to understanding whether the KGB had any involvement with Oswald or the assassination. The release of records related to Nosenko was also a point of discussion during ARRB meetings concerning the JFK assassination records.
